article.title: A Low-Mass Exoplanet Candidate Detected By ${\it K2}$ Transiting the Praesepe M Dwarf JS 183

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the K2 light curve of JS 183, as depicted in Figure 1, primarily show?
choices: Evolving starspot modulation with an amplitude of ~2% and a period of ~24 days
A flat light curve with no significant variability
Transits of the planet with a depth of ~7% and a duration of ~3 hours
A linear trend indicating a change in stellar brightness

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of Figure 2 in the context of the article?
choices: To show the individual transits of JS 183 in detail, using the detrended version of the light curve.
To illustrate the difference between the SAP and PDC light curves of JS 183.
To demonstrate the effectiveness of the K2SC Gaussian Process-based systematics correction algorithm.
To highlight the long-term trends present in the SAP light curve.

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be concluded from the comparison of the K2 and USNO light curves shown in Figure 3?
choices: The USNO observations are significantly affected by systematic noise and cannot confirm the properties of the transit.
The GP-transit model successfully reproduces the large-scale structure of both light curves, supporting the reliability of the transit detection.
The transit is only visible in the K2 light curve, indicating that it is likely a false positive.
The USNO observations reveal additional transits that were not detected in the K2 data.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 9 depict, and what key result does it support?
choices: Radial velocity measurements of JS 183, showing a periodic signal indicative of the planet.
A spectral energy distribution (SED) fit of JS 183, yielding a stellar radius consistent with other methods and supporting the reliability of the planet parameters.
The transit light curve of JS 183 with different models overplotted, demonstrating the best-fit model.
The distribution of stellar densities for late-type exoplanet hosts, highlighting the unusual density of JS 183.

multiple_choice_question.text: According to Table 7, which lists the final properties of the JS 183 system, what is the estimated mass of the star and its uncertainty?
choices: 0.44 ± 0.04 solar masses
0.32 ± 0.02 solar masses
<1.67 Jupiter masses
480 ± 23 Kelvin
